claim: When a Hunter is hit with a handkerchief by the Guardian, that player switches to the Bear role, the Bear moves to the Guardian role, and the Guardian changes to the Hunter role (see Figure 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: The roles in the Bear-Guardian and Hunter Game.

claim: Figure 7 shows the behaviors of the three roles in positive and negative emotional states.
title: Figure 7.
caption: The intensity of positive and negative emotions in the Bear, Guardian, and Hunter roles.

claim: Three triads stand out from the 10 possible emotional triads due to the positive or negative emotion in each of the three roles (see Figure 8).
title: Figure 8.
caption: Orientation of emotional triads in the Bear role.

claim: Relating these results to the emotional map shown above (see Figure 8), it can be deduced that these are emotional states of well-being elicited by being able to change roles.
title: Figure 8.
caption: Orientation of emotional triads in the Bear role.

claim: The cross-table statistical test relating the three types of comments (role, motor interaction and motor aggressiveness) to the emotional triads found significant differences (p = 0.041; Cramer’s V = 0.41; see Figure 9).
title: Figure 9.
caption: Orientation of emotional triads in the Guardian role.

claim: ON_GN_CP (orange color); ON_GP_CP (yellow color); and OP_GP_CP (blue color; see Figure 10).
title: Figure 10.
caption: Orientation of emotional triads in the Hunter role.

claim:
Although no significant differences were found, there was a tendency for emotional well-being to refer to role characteristics (n = 13) and motor aggression (n = 9).

"It has given me much joy to be able to hit my partner in the middle" C12
The itinerary of emotional meanings in each of the three roles
Figure 5 shows the relationship between the emotional orientation of the three groups of comments (role, motor interaction and motor aggressiveness) for each role (Bear, Guardian, Hunter).
title: Figure 5.
caption: Itinerary of the emotional meanings in the three roles. The thickness of the lines corresponds to the frequency of comments. The thicker the lines, the more comments there are.

claim:
The motor aggressiveness dimension projected three thick solid lines in the Bear role (OC, OP, ON), two thick lines of positive and negative emotion in the Guardian role (GP, GN) and one thick line of positive emotion in the Hunter role (CP).The emotional itinerary in the chained role changes

title: Figure 6.
caption: Emotional itinerary in the chained roles. The thickness of the lines corresponds to the frequency of comments. The thicker the lines, the more comments there are.

claim:
Open in a new tab
Emotional itineraries (groups of association rules) based on the emotional meaning of the Bear associated with Motor Aggression by support, confidence and lift measures.In the first emotional pathway (group 1 of association rules) of Figure 11, the emotional meanings of the Bear to aggression were linked to rule 3 (confidence value = 0.422; high lift value = 1.46), subsequently associated with the emotional triad Bear Negative-Guardian Positive-Hunter Positive.
title: Figure 11.
caption: Emotional itineraries (groups of association rules) based on the emotional meaning of the Bear associated with Motor Aggression by support, confidence and lift measures.

claim: The Bear, Guardian and Hunters is a proper theater of life in which the actors play and act as a whole, each person integrating meaning into each of the three roles in which he or she is involved (see Figure 12).
title: Figure 12.
caption: The chained role changes network. Emotions and status/power motor interactions. The line represents the change of role. The dot corresponds to the role. The loop over the Hunter role shows that when a role change occurs, some players remain in the same role, as only one hunter changes to the Bear role.s

claim: Figure 11 highlights four significant groups of association rules with different meaning paths and emotional triads.
title: Figure 11.
caption: Emotional itineraries (groups of association rules) based on the emotional meaning of the Bear associated with Motor Aggression by support, confidence and lift measures.

claim: In the first emotional pathway (group 1 of association rules) of Figure 11, the emotional meanings of the Bear to aggression were linked to rule 3 (confidence value = 0.422; high lift value = 1.46), subsequently associated with the emotional triad Bear Negative-Guardian Positive-Hunter Positive.
title: Figure 11.
caption: Emotional itineraries (groups of association rules) based on the emotional meaning of the Bear associated with Motor Aggression by support, confidence and lift measures.
